XI.	Management Program
Klondike has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Matt Erdley, Vice President of Engineering, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.

ptly addressed. 
	Compliance Audit - Klondike has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Klondike PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed. The next compliance audit will be conducted by May 2, 2025.  
	Hot Work Permits - Klondike has developed a best management practice for hot work.  Klondike's hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration system were reviewed on April 26, 2022.
 

VII.	Five-Year Accident History
The Klondike facility has not experienced an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VIII.	Emergency Action Program
Klondike has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Klondike has conducted training to provide employees proper evacuation procedures and has interacted (i.e. onsite meetings) with the Local Fire Departments. 

Trained and authorized Klondike personnel will act as members of the emergency action team and will be responsible for investigating and assisting the Local Fire Departments (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. 

The facility has multiple windsocks onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.  

The current Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 

IX.	Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.
 

X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Klondik

the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
	Management of Change - Klondike has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as other procedures are documented. 

 

	Pre-Startup Review - Klondike has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
	Mechanical Integrity - Klondike has developed a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Klondike formalized maintenance procedures for the refrigeration system in January, February, and March 2022.
	Contractor Qualifications - Klondike has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Klondike and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.
	Incident Investigation - Klondike has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are prom

rement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
 
	Employee Participation - Klondike has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
	Process Safety Information - Klondike maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed on March 10, 2022.
	Process Hazard Analysis - Klondike has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensured a PHA was conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Klondike conducted a thorough, initial, PHA study for the refrigeration system on February 3-4, and March 8-10, 2022.
	Operating Procedures - Klondike has developed a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Klondike developed initial operating procedures for the refrigeration system during January and February 2022.  Annually, the operating procedures are reviewed and certified as accurate.
	Training - Klondike has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating

safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.

III.	Facility Identification
The Klondike facility is located at W7839 State Road 81 in Monroe, Wisconsin.  Klondike is a cheese and yogurt manufacturing facility. 

The NAICS code for the facility is 311513.  A large portion of the facility is refrigerated to preserve raw materials and products.   

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating coolers and process equipment throughout the facility. 

The amount of ammonia currently onsite has been estimated at approximately 28,000 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used for to cool process equipment, production rooms, and coolers.  

An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 

IV.	Hazard Assessment - Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario. 

V.	Hazard Assessment - Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 

VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program has been developed to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The first audit of the PSM program will occur by May 2, 2025, in compliance with the requi
